1.name: Ali
1.medical_history:
Allergic to penicillin, has asthma, had an ACL surgery in 2020
VISIT: Patient reported feeling nauseous and lightheaded over the past 24 hours. No vomiting, fever, or recent trauma. Likely cause is dehydration or a viral illness. Blood pressure was slightly low. No signs of acute distress or neurological abnormalities. Key points: 1. Stay hydrated, sip fluids throughout the day. 2. Rest and avoid sudden movements to prevent dizziness. 3. Monitor symptoms; seek care if they worsen. 4. Remind all medical professionals of penicillin allergy. (Medication: Meclizine 25 mg (for nausea and dizziness). Take 1 tablet by mouth every 8 hours as needed. May cause drowsiness; avoid driving or operating heavy machinery. Do not take with alcohol.) - Added by omarhossameldin2016@gmail.com on 2025-07-30

2.name: Peter
2.current_medication: Ketoconazole 2% shampoo -  - 3x/week; Hydroxyzine 25 mg - 25 mg - at night

6.name: Eyad Ayman
6.medical_history: VISIT: Discussed skin itching (pruritus), likely due to dry skin or mild eczema. Diagnosis: Mild atopic dermatitis (eczema). Patient should avoid irritants, moisturize regularly, and follow medication instructions. (Medications: Hydrocortisone 1% cream – Apply thin layer to affected areas twice daily for 7 days. Do not use on face or broken skin. Cetirizine 10 mg – Take one tablet daily, preferably at night. May cause drowsiness. Emollient (CeraVe, Eucerin, or similar) – Apply to whole body 2–3 times daily, especially after bathing. Post-Visit Instructions: Avoid hot showers, harsh soaps, and scented products. Use fragrance-free laundry detergent. Wear soft, breathable fabrics. Watch for redness, swelling, oozing, or worsening itch. Follow-Up: Return in 2–3 weeks or sooner if no improvement. Follow-up: Routine dermatology visit. No tests needed at this time.) - Added by omarhossameldin2016@gmail.com on 2025-07-30

7.name: Eyad Nasif
7.current_medication: Paracetamol 500 mg - 500 mg - per day; Cetirizine 10 mg - 10 mg - daily

appointments.symptoms: Itchy skin and hair, tried creams but it gets itchier everywhere

post_visit_records.visit_summary: Persistent itching on skin and scalp. Tried OTC creams with no relief. No new soaps/detergents. Diagnosis: Likely chronic dermatitis or possible fungal infection. Key points: 1. Stop all current creams. 2. Avoid scratching to prevent infection. 3. Keep skin dry and clean.

medications.name: Ketoconazole 2% shampoo
medications.instructions: Use on scalp and affected skin areas. Leave on for 5 mins before rinsing. May cause drynessâ€”use mild moisturizer after.

medications.name: Hydroxyzine 25 mg
medications.instructions: Take 1 tablet at night for itching. May cause drowsiness. Avoid alcohol.

post_visit_records.instructions: Don’t use scented soaps or lotions. Wear loose, breathable clothing. Watch for redness, swelling, or oozing—may indicate infection. Return in 2 weeks if no improvement. Sooner if rash worsens. Consider skin scraping or allergy testing if unresolved.
post_visit_records.next_appointment: Return in 2 weeks if no improvement.

post_visit_records.visit_summary: Eyad reported symptoms of runny nose and sore throat starting 2 days ago. No fever, no difficulty breathing, no ear pain. Thought that it's likely viral upper respiratory infection (common cold). No signs of bacterial infection at this time.

medications.name: Paracetamol 500 mg
medications.instructions: Take 1 tablet every 6 hours as needed for sore throat or discomfort. Do not exceed 4g per day. May cause liver damage if overdosed.

medications.name: Cetirizine 10 mg
medications.instructions: Take 1 tablet daily at night for runny nose. May cause drowsiness.

post_visit_records.instructions: Illness is self-limiting, usually resolves in 5–7 days. No antibiotics needed. Focus on symptom relief and hydration. Drink plenty of fluids. Rest, avoid cold air and smoke. Use humidifier if available. Watch for: high fever > 38.5°C, ear pain, shortness of breath, or symptoms lasting >7 days. No restrictions, but reduce physical activity until symptoms improve. Return if no improvement after 7 days, sooner if fever develops or symptoms worsen.
